item.title: “Impose an embargo on Russian oil and gas exports. All these sanctions are incomplete. They have been threatened, but not yet implemented.” Volodymyr Zelensky calls for Western-imposed economic measures to go further, on “The Economist Asks” https://t.co/OQACAbTBgX
A national­-security law imposed on Hong Kong in 2020 has had an “insidious effect” on the courts, says a British barrister https://t.co/QxXpH86iPi
For a Czech refugee, America was a haven of peace, democracy and freedom. She never took it for granted https://t.co/FJGY1mvCUg
The new Taliban are beginning to look a lot like the old Taliban https://t.co/DULl6HBIwm
The bodies of 410 civilians have so far been found around Kyiv, said the Ukrainian prosecutor-general. Nobody doubts that the final toll will be much higher https://t.co/Lx6TmdDBf1
In the absence of alcohol, sweet treats unite the Middle East https://t.co/4voyz95oev
Society bombards us with instructions to be happier, fitter and richer. Why have we become so dissatisfied with being ordinary? https://t.co/cQ3tAbt2j7
The Centre for Global Development, a think-tank, estimates that 40m people worldwide will be pushed into extreme poverty as a result of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/c540vHltSh

There is evidence of summary executions and random murders—war crimes on a terrible scale. That will redouble Ukrainian resistance, spur Western help and set back already faint hopes for peace https://t.co/CWbLk3ejNU
The goal of a spin dictator is to appear to allow political competition while making it nearly impossible in practice https://t.co/MUwbCPuM8k
We verified reports of what appear to be summary executions https://t.co/bgSxhWeIju
This week’s cartoon from KAL: https://t.co/poJHfICdbK https://t.co/mvv8jG0WnI

“We believe in victory. It’s impossible to believe in anything else.”
The Economist’s editor-in-chief, Zanny Minton Beddoes, travelled to the heart of the Ukrainian war effort to interview President Volodymyr Zelensky https://t.co/Ssque10XDc

A decisive victory for Ukraine would deter yet another Russian invasion. The more convincingly Ukraine can see off the Russian army, the more able it will be to resist the compromises that could poison the peace https://t.co/9M2Qv1FNdj

Years of progress are imperilled. Over 1m school-age girls have been sent home from school. Women have been purged from most workplaces, and are banned from travelling long distances without a male chaperone https://t.co/P46myTy839
Volodymyr Zelensky does not know when or how the war will end, but he knows that “it will end with us still standing here defending” https://t.co/ei1ZbS3jeX
The world, its troubles and their possible solutions were utterly absorbing. She wanted to give freedom and democracy to everyone https://t.co/X7ZM9LTMuz

“Some small cities have been destroyed. There are no people there anymore. And no houses. All that’s left is the name.” Volodymyr Zelensky tells @zannymb and @arkadyostrovsky about the destruction war has brought to his country, on “The Economist Asks” https://t.co/IqGZic6JRu
After redrawing voting districts in 2014, Fidesz won 91% of constituency seats and a two-thirds supermajority overall, despite getting just 45% of the vote https://t.co/4THfgv3zBo
The White House reckons the new tax would bring in $360bn over the next decade https://t.co/Nr5oxlpCSD

Russia will have to deal with the risk of further and perhaps more ambitious counterattacks by Ukraine—which are possible, judging by Volodymyr Zelensky’s appeals to the West for heavier kit https://t.co/vLQtQmMBB6
Kharkiv is largely Russian-speaking and used to be instinctively Russophile. Most of its residents are shocked by the Russian attack https://t.co/j3sJG2GkZV

Vladimir Putin “props up” Alexander Lukashenko’s regime, says @Tsihanouskaya. “The West’s weakness has led to Belarus becoming an accomplice in the most brutal European conflict since the second world war” https://t.co/26ZhqEFrAZ
To still blame NATO for Russia’s war on Ukraine is “frankly, absurd”, argues @IvoHDaalder in a guest essay https://t.co/R1601acPeA
The Biden administration dubs the new proposal a “billionaire minimum income tax” https://t.co/KI2CWvF2OP

In Vladimir Putin’s world honesty is weakness. His power is based on secrecy and deception. Volodymyr Zelensky’s strength lies in his openness and his ability to hear and reflect what people want of him https://t.co/xp1NxZQUKo

Saudi Arabia and Palestinians were notably absent from a recent flurry of diplomacy in the Middle East. It shows how low the Palestinian cause has fallen on Arab states’ agenda https://t.co/4NqY3c5LT9

A strong, democratic Ukraine would thwart Russia’s expansionism because its borders would be secure. Eventually Russia, following Ukraine’s example, would be more likely to solve its problems by reform at home rather than adventures abroad https://t.co/4NPsp5iRMA

Connecting human brains to computers could provide the biggest single upgrade to human intelligence since our species evolved. Brain-computer interfaces are coming. But are we ready? https://t.co/bey7hGpwmX
In the eyes of Indian generals, many of the country’s prestige military toys, such as nuclear-powered submarines and hypersonic cruise missiles, rely on Russian inputs https://t.co/APvp5LQM3E
The brother of a disgraced prime minister, Shehbaz Sharif has been plagued by accusations of nepotism and corruption https://t.co/mVzmuMHxoX
Breaking with pacifist precedent, Japan sent bulletproof vests to Ukraine’s army. It also cracked open its doors to refugees https://t.co/izvXVS9GZB
Abe Shinzo met Vladimir Putin 27 times between 2012 and 2020. But under Kishida Fumio, Japan is backing Ukraine and beside the West https://t.co/gH1575r5eV

If Ukraine had been a member of NATO, Vladimir Putin would have “thought twice” before starting a war, argues America’s former ambassador to the organisation in a guest commentary for The Economist https://t.co/bWgyf3fByl

“We believe in victory. It’s impossible to believe in anything else.” Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, speaks to The Economist’s editor-in-chief @zannymb and Russia editor @arkadyostrovsky, on a special episode of “The Economist Asks” podcast https://t.co/b10socDcxz
It is clear that Russia’s military top brass are suffering unusual attrition. Why? https://t.co/ySmtfxtEYo
It is the American president who seems frightened of tangling with Vladimir Putin, not the other way around https://t.co/OALNayA7gT

The Economist’s editor-in-chief, Zanny Minton Beddoes, travelled to the heart of the Ukrainian war effort to interview Volodymyr Zelensky.
In a wide-ranging interview, the Ukrainian president discussed the state of the war and why Putin must be defeated https://t.co/dmx8o1aGfr
The goal of a spin dictator is to appear to allow political competition while making it nearly impossible in practice https://t.co/UdEh6wv86A
Ukraine has won the first phase of the war simply by surviving. Now it needs to advance, and so Volodymyr Zelensky needs redoubled Western help https://t.co/FRpjQ86jB2
What does Volodymyr Zelensky believe victory will look like? “Victory is being able to save as many lives as possible...because without this nothing would make sense.” https://t.co/8tEVpLW6NR
Judges from Britain’s highest court have been doing double duty on Hong Kong’s since 1997. But this legacy of the city’s past will not feature in its future https://t.co/X4UwUhXwKh
In just one month, the refugees leaving Ukraine already outnumber those who left Iraq in 1991, Afghanistan in 2000, Syria in 2013 and Venezuela in 2018 https://t.co/lHKbOUnkid
After redrawing voting districts in 2014, Fidesz won 91% of constituency seats and a two-thirds supermajority overall, despite getting just 45% of the vote https://t.co/12t9g3YbKI
The official Indian response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has been so cold and tight-lipped that it has left everyone wondering where the world’s largest democracy stands https://t.co/GcPZiIfXtF
The female literacy rate in Afghanistan more than doubled between 2000 and 2018 to 30%. Now a generation of girls is falling behind https://t.co/RLnlOo8Xsk
Economists in the Biden administration have calculated that the 400 wealthiest American families pay an average federal income-tax rate of just 8% https://t.co/5qrr3MQe8l
Not only could a victory for Ukraine against Russia invigorate the cause of democracy, but it would also enhance European security https://t.co/KJ8279kljU

On March 25th Zanny Minton Beddoes, editor-in-chief of The Economist, travelled to Kyiv to interview Volodymyr Zelensky.
Here is the inside story of how she and Arkady Ostrovsky, The Economist’s Russia editor, made it into the Ukrainian president’s war room https://t.co/HHJ1cuYUmD

Russian forces have paid a heavy price for their attack on Ukraine. Though Russia claims that only 1,351 of its soldiers have died, American and Ukrainian officials say the true number is much higher https://t.co/8LsTiemyur
